oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Newman, Robert Loftin (1827-1912)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Wallace Warfield and Son [William Laban]
Warfield, William Wallace, portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This formal portrait is of a well-dressed young gentlemen, posed with a young boy holding his arm and a dog seated below.

William Wallace Warfield was a prominent resident of Clarksville, Tennessee, when artist Robert Loftin Newman opened a studio there in 1858. Newman's large portrait of Warfield and his young son, William Laban, is one of a pair painted for wealthy patrons just prior to the Civil War. Newman was one of the few professional artists in Tennessee to join the Confederate forces. Aside from a post-war pair of portrait drawings of generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson, Newman is not known to have created any war-themed works.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portraits
